subject: Re: [junit] Behavior of optional string messages for assert methods?
msgSnippet: What, exactly, does your assert look like your test? It sounds like you have used the signature that expects a string and the assertion argument(s), instead of
messageBody:
What, exactly, does your assert look like your test?

It sounds like you have used the signature that expects a string and the assertion argument(s), instead of using the one with just the assertion argument(s),...though I've never tried it, to see if I get the results you are seeing, and I've never seen the results you are seeing to know of another reason why you would get it.

Please paste your assertion, so that we can help you further.


thanks,
Dianne

-------------- Original message --------------
From: "yogamatt1970" <yogamatt1970@...>
OK, apologies in advance if this has been asked before - I searched
around the forum here and could not find an answer to my question:

I've noticed that if I don't supply the optional string argument to
many (perhaps all) of Junit's assert methods, I get an error message
that looks like this:
[junit] null
[junit] junit.framework.AssertionFailedError

I find this to be confusing. However, if I include the optional
string argument, then that message is displayed in the output.
I have a very high opinion of the Junit framework and find it hard to
believe that the null message is standard behavior. It feels so
clunky, almost as if Junit does not check to see if the optional
argument was passed or not. My guess is that there's a property
somewhere which allows me disable the null error but I can't find it.
My other option is to just add a string argument to all of the
asserts in all of my unit tests (at this point, not that many although
it would still be a pain and would probably take me at least a few hours).
Any and all help is appreciated.




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
